This Company's system of submarine telegraph

South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HASELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: RAILWAYS IN THE MARIOUT DISTRICT
div.p: It is reported that the Daira Khassa of H.H. the Khedive, after completing the ex- tension of the Alexandria-Ain Hammam line to Marsa Matrough vià Sidi Abd el Rah- man, contemplates a further prolongation of the railway to the frontier of Tripoli. Some of our native contemporaries assert that the line will be carried on to Derna from poli- tical moves, and that its extension into Tripoli will enable the Egyptian Government to lay claims to part of Barca should the Tripoli question ever come up for solution. We are sure that if ever the Mariout line passes the Tripoli frontier, the Egyptian and British Governments are certain to press no claims for the ownership of Barca against its present rulers or the European Power which is most likely to succeed them. The rela- tions between Egypt and England on the one hand and Italy on the other are far too friendly for such an idea to be entertained. The friendship of Italy is worth many Barcas and Tripolis, and we strongly deprecate the publication of political prophecies which are liable to cause a certain amount of alarm among our more nervous Italian contempo- raries. In any acase the assent of the Sultan of Turkey is required before any idea of railway extension across the vague frontier of Barca can be entertained.

But setting aside the question whether a line from Matrouh to the frontier would pay, we are of the opinion that there is another part of the Mariout country where a railway is very much wanted. A line from Amriya or Sidi Abd el Kader to Gheta or Kom el Hanish would link the Daira Khassa's Mariout line with the Delta Light Railways, and by opening a large district to trade would bring a considerable amount of traffic both to the Daira Khassa and to the Light Railways. The line suggested would have no engineering difficulties to encounter on the 30 kilometres of its course, and would serve some 80,000 feddans irrigated in part from the Nubarieh and Hagir Canals and in part bearing a rain crop. The barley grown in this area is in great demand for brewing, and the construction of this line would without doubt stimulate its production and induce proprietors in the rain crop areas to adopt certain agricultural measures such as the sinking of wells and the storage of rain water in cisterns which the district greatly needs. We may add that the land- owners in this district hold their proper- ties by titles granted them by the decree of 1884, while too many proprietors in other parts of the Mariout country have bought from the Bedouins what was not theirs to sell, and in many cases have never had their titles recognized by the Egyptian Government. FOr some time past certain exporters of barley and landowners in the above-mentioned district have been discussing the possibility of opening a motor car service between Amriya and Kom el Hanish. In our opinion the construction of a light railway would be more useful for the development of the country and preferable from many points of view. Perhaps the Daira Khassa or the Delta Light Railway Company will step into the breach. The construction of such a line should, we think be as easy from the engineering as it should be profitable from the commercial point of view.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d’Hote Luncheons & Dinners Served on the Terrace.
ORCHESTRA PLAYS 6 TO 11.30 P.M
DELIGHTFUL SITUATION - SEA BREEZES.
M. Witte, in an interview, said that the Tsar desires peace, but that he fears that the Japanese terms will be such as to prevent an agreement. In that case Russia is prepared to fight for year.
(Reuter.)
M. Witte, in an interview, stated that Russia was not in any way obliged to submit to unacceptable conditions; she can continue the war for several years.
The newspapers state that the internal situation is rapidly becoming worse.
(Havas.)
General Linievitch reports that on the 14th inst the Japanese were bombarding Naibuchi on the south-western coast of Saghalien. (R.)

The withdrawal of the redistribution scheme was due to the decision of the Speaker that the complex proposals contained in Mr. Bal- four's resolution must be taken seperately and not voted in a single resolution. This would greatly have protracted the debate.

The announcement that the Unionist party meets to-day to consider its attitude towards the redistribution scheme and the remaining business of the session has excited many con- jectures in the lobbies.
(Reuter.)

At the Unionist meeting Mr. Balfour justi- fied his action with regard to the redistribution scheme, and earnestly exhorted the party to continue loyally to support the Government. The meeting unanimously voted confidence in Mr. Balfour.
(Reuter.)
The visit of the fleet to Brest is recognised as having produced the best feeling between the two peoples and navies.
(Reuter.)
The British fleet has left.
(Reuter.)
The funeral of the victims of teh Farfadet was imposing.
(Havas.)
Yorkshire beat Hampshire by an innings and 167 runs. M.C.C. beat Derbyshire by an innings and 252 runs.
(Reuter.)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: His Beatitude Kyrillos VIII, Melchite Patriarch, leaves Alexandria on Saturday next for Syria.
Mr. Webb, Acting Adviser to the Ministry of Public Works, arrived at San Stefano from Cairo last night.
M.A. Boinet Bey, Secretary-General to the Ministry of Public Works, has been granted 2 1/2 months leave, from July 29.
Ramzi Gress Bey, director of the Legal Department, has been granted 3 months' leave of absence, from the 22nd inst.
Mr. C.G. Crawley, director of the Technical Service Ministry of Public Works, has also been granted 2 1/2 months' leave of absence, from the 23rd inst.
A telegram from our Port Said Correspon- dent states that Captain Max Chevalier de Leitgeb, principal agent of the Austrian Lloyd S.S. Company at that port, died in Austria on the 17th inst.
Cpat. F.H.A. Wollaston, 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade, has been granted leave of absence from July 17 to October 17.
Mr. H.W. Tite, chief inspector of teh International Sleeping Car Co., left Cairo last night for Cyprus.
THE BRINDISI MAIL will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 9.30 p.m. to-day.
MATARIEH LINE.-A credit of L.E. 9,000 has been opened for the doubling of the Marg section of the Matarieh line.
STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in He- louan during the night of Friday and at day- light on Saturday will be poisoned by the police.
BATHING FATALITY.-The soldier drowned while bathing near Mustapha Pasha on the 16th inst. was Private Th. Mills, of teh 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers.
A SUNSPOT of very exceptional size was noticed from the Helouan Observatory at sunset on Sunday last. The spot, which was almost in the centre of the sun, was distinctly visible to the naked eye.
FALL FROM A TRAM CAR.-A lad named Spiro Karmi Fakhouri, eight years of age, fell from a moving tram yesterday and sustained a nasty wound in the head. He has been re- moved to hospital.
LIFONTI'S MUSIC STORES have been removed from the premises in Cherif Pasha street to the new Lifonti Building in Rosetta-road. The inauguration of the new establishment will take place in a few days.

A CHILDREN'S BALL will be given on the terrace of teh San Stefano Casino on Friday afternoon next, the music being supplied by the Bracale orchestra. Packets of chocolate will be distributed to the children of abonnés.

SUEZ CANAL.,-21 vessels passed through the Canal on the 15th and 16th inst., of which 13 were British, 1 French, 4 German, 1 Dutch, 1 Norwegian, 1 Russian. The receipts for the two days were frs. 575,092.14, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 4,702,982.31.

THE MAHMAL THEFT.-The inquiry in the case of the theft of £8,000 from the Mahmal escort, which has been occupying the attention of the Parquet for the past few weeks, has been concluded and Andraous Meloka, Ibrahim Machour, Said Hannalla, and Mankarious have been committed for trial before the Court of Assizes.

MODEL WORKSHOPS.-Mr. Wm. Shearer, professor at the Polytechnic Schools, has been appointed director of teh model workshops which will shortly be opened at Assiout. These schools are being arranged on the same prin- ciples as those of Cairo, which are proving of such benefit by training young natives to become skilled workmen in various trades.

PRIZE DISTRIBUTION.-The annual distri- bution of prizes at the Collège St. François- Xavier will take place to-morrow at 5 p.m., and will be presided over by M. Maurice Campana, acting French Consul. The pro- gramme of the afternoon's entertainment in- cludes a one-act comedy entitled Le Commis- saire est Bon Enfant.

THE LATE SHEIKH MOHAMED ABDOU.-We hear that last Friday the Imam of the Tirbana Mosque, Alexandria, thought fit to introduce some very unfair criticism of the late Sheikh Mohamed Abdou into his sermon. The con- gregation bore it till the Imam began to attack the belief of the late Grand Mufti, when all rose up and left the mosque for another, where they completed their prayers.

THE COTTON WORM.-In the July number of teh "Bulletin de l'Union Syndicale des Agriculteurs d'Egypte" M. Poilay Bey devotes several paragraphs to the campaign against the cotton worm, in which he pays a well- deserved compliment to the activity and perserverance of Mr. Machell, to whose vigorous initiative the success of the campaign against this pest is mainly due.

ST. MARK'S CHURCH, ALEXANDRIA.-Next Sunday, 23rd inst., the services will be in the memorial chapel, as the restoration of the church is still proceeding. The services are: 8 a.m., Holy Communion; 11 a.m., morning prayer and address; 6.15 p.m., evening prayer. The chapel can accomo- date 25 people, and chairs are placed outside from which the service can be heard quite well.

FAGALLAH jESUIT COLLEGE.-On Monday, the Jesuit College of the Holy Family at Fagallah celebrated its prize-giving. Over a thousand persons were present, M. Bonin, French Chargé d'Affaires, presiding. Mme Bonin, M. de Chaffault, M. Donziech, Mgr. Noury, M.T. Caneri, Chélu Bey, and many other well-known Cairenes were pre- sent. M. De la Boulinière's, prize was won by M. Georges Tabbakh, the final certificate by MM. Georges Sabbakh, Faiz Khenzam, Nikola Commissopoule, Henri Rousso, and the French and English prizes by Raphael Nakhlé and Fanzi Abdou. French, English, and Arabic dramatic pieces were given and the Egyptian Army band aided the studen musi- cians to make the afternoon a very pleasant one.
The Grand Cherif of Mecca is dead. (R.)

The Emir el Hag's report on the pilgrimage of 1904 contains some interesting references to the deceased Cherif which we quote in full The first deaals with the robberies and assaults committed on Egyptian pilgrims by the moutawefs and auxiliaries of the Cherif:-

"I had to write on this matter to the Wali and the Cherif. They replied by denying these facts, and as I offered to prove them officially, the Cherif replied that it was not my business to interfere in questions concerning the pilgrims. When I wanted to set their com- plaints before him he likewise answered that I had no right to interfere, and kept on repeating the phrase over and over again."
Another passage reveals the Cherif in an even less amiable light:-

"In an interview with the Cherif I learned that he wished we should follow the Rabigh route instead of that to Yambo. I pointed out to him that this change could not be made without the authorisation of the Egyptian Government. Moreover the Wali had no offi- cial orders on the subject of the change of route recommended by the Cherif, but only letters from the Governor of Yambo in which it was stated that there was not sufficient water at Yambo. I learnt that the route chosen by the Cherif was long and infested by evil- doers."
The Cherif recently received letters from the Imam Yahia of the Yemen, which perhaps explains his death, a Turkish garrison being stationed at Mecca.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin records three fresh cases at Alexandria, one of which was fatal. One of the two cases admit- ted to hospital was that of a Greek maid servant employed in a house near Rosetta road, the other is that of a native girl living at Kom el-Shougafa. The fatal case was that of the latter's uncle, who was found dead at his house in Kom el-Shougafa. one recovery took place at Alexandria and another at Zifta.

div.head: THE DRAINAGE QUESTION.
div.p: The question of sewage disposal (says the "Time" Alexandria correspondent), which has for some time been occupying the attention both of the Cairo and Alexandria authorities, is likely to increase rather than to diminish in importance in the future. Alexandria, of course, possesses a natural receptacle from the effluvia which prevail over thew town, to a greater or less extent, for 300 out of the 365 days of the year. The evil will undoubtedly be minimised by the work of laying a large outfall drain to serve the Greek quarter and neighbourhood east of the town, upon which themunicipal authorities areat present engaged. This outfall is laid along the most of the old Rosetta gate fortifications, and it connects with the principal sewer circling the east bay beneath the new quay esplanade. Further extensions will probably be required to render the treatment radically effective.

It may seem remarkable (adds the corres- pondent) that Cairo, a city of three-quarters of a million inhabitants, should be without an organised system of drainage; yet such is the case. Moreover, the health of the town exhibits no symptom of being unduly affected by this circumstance, owing, in great part, if not altogether, to the admirable service of the limited company that effects the sweage clearances of Cairo generally. The company has established a sweage farm in the desert near Abbassieh, where it converts the waste matters collected into various artificial ma- nures. Periodically, reformers return to the question of a system of urban sewage; but financial considerations, coupled with the ad- mitted efficiency of the present method, have hitherto deterred the Government from taking action, and may continue so to do for an indefinite period. Sir William Willcocks is believed to compute the cost of the initial and partial installation at a sum approaching a million sterling, and the annual expense of upkeep at about £20,000.

div.head: THE IBRAHIMIEH RESCUE.
div.p: At about 11 a.m. on Friday, the 14th inst., an old Greek, after visiting the Greek Hospital, where his wife lay ill, went to Ibrahimieh for a bathe. While swimming he was taken out by the current and was soon in grave danger.

There were about 50 or 60 people bathing close by, none of whom appeared to have thought of attempting a rescue, or indeed of doing anything, with the exception of a Greek woman, who realised the situation and called for help.

The attendant usually present at teh bath- thing place seems to have quitted his post or to have been unwilling to run any risks. Luckily a British soldier riding past at the time saw what was the matter, dismounted, threw off his clothes, and resued the drowning man, who had lost consciousness. The soldier revived him, and, having refused to give his name or accept even a cognac, dressed and rode off.

It is not possible for the authorities to erect sign-boards at our principal bathing places, projecting some feet above the surface of the water, to warn bathers against venturing near certain spots where fatalities are of constant occurrence.

div.head: MOSQUE FOR LONDON.
KHEDIVE SUPPORTS SCHEME.
div.p: For some time past, a movement has been on foot-one of the most active supporters of which is a well-known and venerated sheikh of Alexandria,-to erect a mosque in London, which would be a rallying place for the West- ern followers of Mohamed, and a training school where missionaries would be instructed in the art of spreading an Eastern faith among a Western people.

IN a recent issue of the "Daily Mirror," it was stated that the foundation-stone of thew mosque would be laid by the Shah of Persia during his forthcoming visit to London, our contemporary adding that "before the year is out the graceful cupolas and slender minarets of the building will rise from among the wilderness of Lambeth factories."

We do not know how much of this is true, but we are inclined to the belief that some considerable time must yet elapse before the mosque can be constructed, as the estimated cost of this structure is £25,000, and of this but a small amount has been collected so far.

The plan of the edifice and its style of archi- tecture have been designed by Mr. Robert Williams, F.R.I.B.A. Architect, of Clifford's Inn, who is now in Alexandria, but leaves for London on Saturday next.
It is said that his Highness the Khedive, during his late visit to England, displayed the greatest interest in the idea, and has promised to give it every support.

The Ameer of Afghanistan has also lavishly contributed £1,000 and it is expected that the Shah of Persia will display his usual lavish generosity in making this fairy-like structure the most beautiful in Europe.

With respect to the proselytising scheme it may be said that many Europeans have already embraced the faith, and the gatherings of the Pan-Islamic society are remarkable for the variety of nationality evidenced by their attendance.

The society takes a much broader view of the religion than the sterner or stricter sect in the Orient do, and do not insist on certain rules which, in the stricter faith, are as neces- sary as baptism is in the Christian Churches.

div.head: WARSHIPS LEAVE PORT SAID.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: H.M.S. Suffolk and Lancaster are leaving the port to-day for Malta. The battleships Albion, Ocean, Centurion, and Vengeance leave at noon for Gibraltar.

div.head: EXHIBITION OF BRITISH MANUFACTURES.
div.p: We hear that an All-British Manufacturers' Exhibition is shortly to be held in Cairo and Alexandria, and we welcome the project as tending to further the commercial relations between this country and Great Britain. Some such stimulus is needed in view of the obvious fact that the increase of English imports into Egypt has not kept pace with the recent marvellous expansion of the trade of the country.
We understand that the idea of holding the exhibition is receiving a good deal of support, and it is hoped that the venture will meet with the success it deserves.

We shall give further particulars of the exhi- bition as plans mature. Meantime, we may state that the consent of the Alexandria Municipality has been obtained for holding the exhibition in the "French Garden" in Mohamed Aly-square, provided the French authorities are agreeable. The promoters hope that the latter's consent will also be obtained.

div.head: STREET OBSTRUCTIONS.
div.p: A correspondent writes:-"Yesterday even- ing, the rue Eglise Debbane was absolutely blocked by three large portable asphalt furnaces on which no lantern whatever was hung to warn vehicles of their presence. At 5.30 a.m. to-day, these furnaces were heated, and the inhabitants of all the houses in the street were compelled to close their windows. The asphalt is detained for a neighbouring house which stands in the middle of a court and garden, but I fail to see why the whole of the street traffic should be impeded and the householders half-choked on that account. The police were informed about the obstruc- tion yesterday evening, without any result as yet."
[At midday to-day the three asphalt boilers were hard at work, sending out quantities of a very evil-smelling steam. Ed., E.G.]

CAIRO'S WATER SUPPLY.-The recent report of Professor H. Bitter, director of the Hygienic Institute of the Sanitary Department, on the quality of the water supply of Cairo, must have reassured a great many people on a sub- ject which is so important in a tropical climate. The water (vide the report) is of splendid natural quality, and the dwellers of Cairo must congratulate themselves on being the happy possessors of such a valuable asset to their health. The fact of the water supply being so excellent will go far to enhance the reputation of the Capital as a winter health resort and ought to give a great impetus to the tourist traffic. The mineral waters of Mr. N. Spathis of Cairo and Alexandria, are manufactured from this water, their purity and wholesome- ness being therefore practically guaranteed by public analysis. Any further recommendation in favor of Spathi's mineral waters is need- less, as not only is the water guaranteed, but all ingredients used are of the highest grade and are obtained from first-class English firms of known and tried reputation.

div.head: THE DEATH OF THE GRAND MUFTI
(AL ZAHER.)
div.p: Those who saw the crowds filling the station and following the coffin of the Grand Mufti through the streets with a throng of notables, ulema, sheikhs, and students, of orphans whose greatest benefactor was the deceased Sheikh, must have realised the grief that overwhelmed the whole assembly. The great Sheikh defended the cause of Islam by his life and writings, boldly meeting those who assert- ed that Islam was opposed to progress, and proved that Islam was no obstacle to social progress or to prosperity in this world or the next. We have not forgotten his articles refuting the contentions of M. Hanotaux and others who asserted that Islam was a decadent faith...We have heard that the Governor of Algiers recently declared that if there were ten men like Sheikh Mohamed Abdou in the Moslem world he would be a willing convert to Islam.

div.head: THE FRENCH FETE.
div.p: Our native contemporaries devote consider- able attention to the French fête, praising its successful organisation and noting the his- torical importance of the capture of the Bastille.

div.head: COTTON GROWING IN KOREA.
div.p: The Canadian Commercial Agent at Yoko- hama reports that a Japanese association has been recently formed in Tokio, under the style of the "Menka Saibai Kyokai" (Cotton Planta- tion Society), with the object of encouraging the cultivation of cotton. It has been decided as a first step to make experimental cultivation in Korea, and experts and labourers will be sent to the peninsula shortly. The selection of experts has been entrusted to the Department of Agriculture and Commerce. The Government, it is said, fully approve of the work of the association, and their assistance is promised as far as possible. Considering the large amount of raw cotton wich Japan is annually import- ing, principally from the United States, it is not surprising that the Japanese should turn their attention towards its cultivation. There are large tracts of land in Korea well adapted to agriculture, and the climatic conditions of the peninsula are, it is stated, not unsuited for plantations of cotton.

div.head: THEN AND NOW.
div.p: There was a historic siginficance in the recent presentation of Senior Sergeant-Major Rule, of the Yeomen of the GUard, to Prince Arisugawa, for the old soldier was Sergeant0 Major of the Lancashire Fusiliers, then the XXth Regiment in the early sixties, when its 2nd Battalion was sent to Japan in conse- quence of an attack on the British Legation at Jeddo.. An article on the subject in the "Lan- cashire Fusiliers' Annual" recalls the fact that in that year a review of the British troops forming the Yokohama garrison was held. The Japanese troops who took part in the parade were clad in chain armour, and as their weapons were swords and bows and arrows they performed their exercises separately. After the review the Japanese were instructed in English drill, and the two properly organised battalions which speedily resulted constituted the beginning of the Japanese Army as we know it to-day.

It should be left on record that the officers mainly responsible for their instruction were Colonels Glencross and De la pere Robinson, and an interesting fact is that before the battalion of the XXth left Yokohama in 1866 the two Japanese battalions took part in an- other review, which was commanded by General (then Colonel) Browne. Viscount Hayashi, whose attention has been called to the matter by Sir Lees Knowles, M.P., has sent a reply which appears in the "Times," saying how well he remembers that some of his old friends used to go to be instructed in drill. There is some justice in the claim that the parade ground of the XXth Regiment was the birthplace of the Japanese Army.
The Moss liner "Menes" sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due here on Friday next.

div.head: (Communication Officielle)
div.p: La Délégationj Municipale s'est réunie le 11 juillet 1905, à 5 h. p.m. sous la présidence de M. Ambr. A. Ralli.
Présents: M.M.Ahmed Bey Eyoub, Soliman Bey Abani, Dr. Schiess Bey, Dr. G. Valensin, membres, A. Wilner, Secrétaire p.i.
La Délégation revise certaines évaluations pour des excédents et emprises et décide de les soumettre à l'approbation de la Commision Municipale.

Communication est donnée d'une note de l'Inspecteur Sanitaire et de M. Piot Bey insistant en raison de la recrudescence des cas de morve, constatés sur divers chevaux sur la nécessité de rendre la melléinisation obligatiore.

La Délégation considérant, d'une part, l'ur- gence qu'il y a de prendre des mesures pour arrêter le mal et, d'autre part, l'intérêt général de la question, au point de vue sanitaire du pays entier, décide de communiquer les rap- ports de ces fonctionnaires au Gouvernement en le priant de vouloir bien édicter un règle- ment à cet effet.
En attendant, les services continueront à prendre toutes les dispositions en leur pouvoir, pour combattre le mal.
La Délégation, vu les devis, décide l'empier- rement de la place située devant le Khedivial Yacht Club, à Ras-el-Tin, moyennant la con- tribution de cette institution.
Une autre dépense pour la modification du tracé de l'empierrement de la rue, sur le pro- longemen de la rue de Ras-el-Tin, est égale- ment autorisée.

La délégation décide de mettre en adjudica- tion les travaux d'empierrement de la rue de la Promenade de Ramleh, près du Casino; toutefois, ce travail ne devera être mis en exécution qu'au mois de Novembre prochain, pour ne pas interrompre la promenade pendant l'été.

Elle adjuge les travaux de confection d'une rue, en prolongement de la rue des Parcs, à M. Moscatelli, au prix de L.E. 115, les travaux de mise en état des trottoirs de la rue Bab- el Melouk, à M. Nicola Calvario, au prix de L.E. 154, et renvoie les effres pour fourni- tures d'imprimés et registres, au rapport des services.

Il est doné communicationh d'une lettre du ministère de l'Intérieur, en réponse au voeu exprimé par la Commission Municipale, ten- dant à la révision du règlement pour les élec- tions municipales du collège des importateurs.

Le Ministre n'est pas d'avis de modifier le nouveau règlement, l'expérience n'en ayant pas encore démontré les inconvénients. La Déléga- tion décide de soumettre cette lettre à la Commission Municipale.

De l'avis conforme de l'Ingénieur en Chef, la Délégation autorise la Cie du Gaz à opérer l'essai d'une lampe dite "Lucas Licht," pour le renforcement de l'éclairage de la rue Chérif Pacha, se réservant de prendre ultérieurement une décision définitive sur le système à em- ployer pour l'augmentation de l'éclairage de la dite rue.

Communication est donnée d'une lettre de l'administration des Gardes-Côtes, tendant à l'effectation d'une partie de la localité du Mex, à l'entrepôt des bois et proposant dans ce but, un nouveau lotissement des terrains de cette localité.

La Délégation tout en renvoyant les nou- veaux tracés à l'examen du Conseil du Tanzim, décide de faire ressortir auprès du Gouverne- ment, en vue des compensations événtuelles, toutes les pertes que ce projet fera subir à la Municipalité, à un point de vue financier, et d'attirer son attention sur les inconvénients sanitaires que certaines des dispositions pro- jetées pourraient rencontrer.
L'Ingénieur en Chef et l'Inspecteur Sanitaire auront à présenter, chacun en ce qui le concerne, un rapport sur la question lequel sera soumis au Gouvernement.

div.head: FAITS CRIMINELS II.-DELITS
(Suite)
div.p: Les dénonciations présentées aux parquets en 1904 s'élèvent à 93.375 dont 67.858 paraissent revêtir un caractère délictueux et se répartissent suivant leur nature en: 285 homicides par imprudence; 4.722 outrages et violences contre les agents de l'autorité; 27.370 coups; 17.152 vols; 541 tentatives de vol; 405 escroqueries; 366 faux en écriture privées; 787 fausses dénonciations, dont 129 en matière de recrutement; 260 faux témoignages; 481 délits de vagabondage et de port d'armes; 120 tentatives de corruption; 133 attentats à la pudeur sans violence; 998 ruptures de ban de surveillance; 2.121 dévasta- tions de culture; 305 empoisonnements de bestiaux; 165 infractions punies par le décret sur le recrutement; 2.930 infractions punies par le décrit sur la peste bovine; 8.817 délits divers.
Le nombre des délits en 1903 était de 63.305, c'est-à-dire qu'il y a une augmentation apparente de 4.553 en 1904.

Mais dans ce chiffre sont compris 2.839 in- fractions se rapportant à la peste bovine, con- formément à un décret promulgué en juillet 1903, qui non seulement créa certains délits nouveaux, mais encore donna au service sani- taire des pouvoirs éténdus pour rédiger des règlements sous la sanction édictée par le décret même. En 1903, il n'y eut que 375 de ces cas, mais depuis cette époque, le service sanitaire a prescrit des mesures qui n'ont pas été éxécutées, d'où le grand nombre de délits de ce genre constatés cette année. Je crois que la peste bovine a presque complètement disparu et que les infractions auxquelles je viens de faire allusion disparaitront des statistiques l'année prochaine. En tout cas, comme elles re- vêtent essentiellement le caractère de contra- ventions (quoiqu'elles soinet qualifiées délits par suite de l'importance attachée aux pré cautions prises contre la peste), comme en outre elles ne sont que temporaires et ne se répar- tissent pas sur l'année 1903 tout entière, il est indispensable si l'on veut établir une compa- raison exacte, de les déduire des totoaux de deux années; nous avons ainsi 62.930 délits en 1903 contre 64.928 en 1904. Il ya lien toute- fois d'ajouter, pour que la comparaison soit juste, les délits transformés en crimes en 1904, de même que nous les avons déduits des crimes de l'année, soit une addition de ce chef, de 575 infractions; ce qui donne un total de 65.503 ou une augmentation de 2.573 sur 1903.

Si nous jetons un coup d'oeuil sur les statis- tiques antérieures, nous constatons que cet excédent est très inférieur à l'augmentation dormale. Depuis 1891, année où pour la pre mière fois les statistiques ont été dressées, les d;elits ont, sauf 1896, régulièrement augmenté et dans les quatre dernières anées (1900, 1901, 1902, 1903) les majorations ont été respective ment de 4.979, 4.290, 8.337 et 5.896. La dimi nution du pourcentage de l'accroissement est suffisamment marquée cette année pour qu'on la considère comme étant de bon augure. Il est également satisfaisant que cette différence en plus provienne surtout d'agressions sans impor tance, qui comptent pour 1.892 de l'excédent et de dénonciations calomineuses qui ont pro gressé de 267; ce dernier chiffre signifie réele ment que les poursuites ont été plus nom breuses. Il n'est pas toujours facile, dans un pays oriental où le droit de porter plainte est d'une si haute importance, d'éviter à la fois trop de relâchement dans la punition de ce qui semble être une dénonciation calomnieuse et une propension trop forte à considérer avec une sévérité excessive ce qui peut être plutôt une exagération qu'une calomnie formulée de propos délibéré. Depuis deux ans on a cru devoir se montrer un peu plus sévère pour les délits de ce genre, ce qui est la cause de cette augmentation apparente. Après déduction de l'excédent fourni par les aggressions et les dénonciations calomnieuses, il nous reste à parler des 279 cas supplémentaires restant. Ils sont tous classés sous la rubrique "divers" c'est- à-dire que ce sont des infractions de peu d'im- portance, non classées. Aucune catégorie de délits spécifiés ne fournit d'accroissement qui vaille la peine d'être mentionné, tandis qu'au contraire certaines diminutions attirent parti culièrement l'attention.

Je suis heureux, par exemple, de pouvoir constater que les vols délictuels (y compris 289 qui sont devenus crimes au cours de l'an née) sont enfin en décroissance, faiblement il est vrai. En 1903 ils ateignaient le chiffre 17.562; en 1904, 17.414, soit 148 de moins. Quelque faible que soit cette amélioration, elle est, j'en ai la conviction, vraiment significative. En effet, pour ne pas remonter plus haut qu'en monté d'année en année d'environ mille par an (11.803 en 1897, contre 17.562 en 1903). Je crois que les peines sévères infligées fréquem ment aux récidivistes par la Cour d'Appel ont commencé à produire quelques résultats, de même que je suis persuadé que les récentes modifications législatives qui ont enrayé, dans une large mesure, le retard dans l'exécution provenant d'appels vexatoires et de ridicules pourvois en cassation, ont déjà exercé une in fluence bienfaisante sur le total général des délits.
Les tentatives de vols sont également en direinution de 280 cas (541 contre 821).

J'ajouterai que l'on a constaté une amélio ration (c'est-à-dire une décroissance) dans les destructions de récoltes sur pied accomplies de propos délibéré qui ont, dans les dernières années, causé tant d'inquiétude, alors que dans mon rapport précédent je devais me déclarer satisfait en constatant que le pourcentage de

l'augmentation était en diminution. Voici le chiffres: 1901, 1.541 cas; 1902, 2.246 cas; 1903, 2.623 cas; 1904, 2.363 cas (y compris 243 infractions que la nouvelle législation a classés parmi les crimes). L'exercice qui vient de s'écouler accuse une diminution de 260 délits, ce qui est très satisfaisant.

Les statistiques des empoisonnements de bestiaux, qui ont une grande analogie avec les destructions de récoltes, nous donnent les ré sultats suivants; 1901, 113 cas; 1902, 177 cas; 1903, 338 cas; 1904, 348 cas (y compris 43 couvellement qualifiés crimes). Si ici nous ne pouvons pas annoncer une diminution, du moins pouvons-nous augurer favorablement de ce que tandis qu'en 1903 les infractions étaient plus élevées du double qu'en 1902, le shiffre de 1904 est à peu près semblable à celui ci de 1903. La progression est donc arrivée à son terme et nous pouvons espérer, sous peu, une diminution.
Je ne crois pas qu'il y ait lieu de s'étendre sur les autres délits; les chiffres sont du reste à peu près identiques pour les deux années.
Il y a eu l'année 1904, 7,14 délits à rai son de chaque 1.000 habitants (d'après le re censement de 1897).
En France en l'année 1896, il y en avait 7,64 à raison de chaque 1.000 habitants.
Le parquet a déféré 37.440 affaires de délits aux tribunaux sommaires et a classé provisoire ment 9.593 affaires
Au 31 décembre 1904 il restait au parquet en arriéré de 2.700 affaires sous examen et en instruction, soit une moyenne de 61 affaires pour chaque parquet.
Les 44 juges sommaires ont jugé 41.666 affaires tant nouvelles qu'arriérées de l'année 1903.
Dans 36.668 affaires, il est intervenu des jugements de condamnation.
Dans 4.743 affaires il est intervenu des juge ments d'acquittement.
Dans 255 il est intervenu des jugements d'incompétence.
La proportion des jugements de condamna tions rendus par les tribunaux sommaires a été de 88% sur l'ensemble des affaires jugés. Cette proportion était de 90% en 1903.

Les 64 markaz auxquel sle pouvoir du parquet pour certains délits a été donné, ont reçu 24.033 dénonciations. De ce chiffre 5.908 ont été classées définitivement; 181 classées provisoirement; 17.167 présentées aux tribunaux de markaz, et au 31 décemgre 1904, il restait au markaz un arriéré de 777 affaires sous examen et en instruction soit une moyenne de 12 affaires pour chaque markaz.

Les tribunaux de markaz ont rendu dans 15.011 affaires des jugements de condamna tion; dans 1.263 affaires il est intervenu des jugements d'acquittement et dans 126 affaires il est intervenu des jugement d'in compétence.
Au 31 décembre 1904, il restait aux rôles des audiences 767 affaires.
La proportion des condamnations à été de 92%.
Les jugements de condamnation ont porté sur 82.030 personnes.

Le total des appels interjetés en 1904 s'élève à 18,061 dont 7,616 contre des jugements rendus jusqu'au 14 avril c'est-à-dire sous le le régime de l'ancien Code, et 10,445 contre des jugements rendus du 15 avril jusqu'à fin décembre, c'est-à-dire sous l'empire du nouveau Code.

Du dit chiffre de 18,061, 624 appels ont été interjetés coutre des jugements des tribunaux de markaz et 17,437 contre des jugements des tribunaux sommaires, c'est-à-dire avec une proportion de 4% pour les premiers et 42% pour les seconds. Cette dernière proportion était de 46% en 1903.

La proportion des jugements sommaires annulés cette année par les tribunaux de pre mière instance jugeant en appel est de 7% des jugements de condamnation et de 33% des jugements d'acquittement. Elle était respecti vement de 8% et de 50% en l'année 1903.
La proportion des jugements annulés par la Cour d'Appel est de 12% des jugements de condamnation et de 23% des jugements d'acquittement. Elle etait respectivement de 13% et de 21% en l'année 1903.

div.head: Jeunes délinquants.
div.p: Pour la commodité, je note ici tous les jugements rendus contre les jeunes délin quants pendant la période du 15 avril jusqu'au 31 décembre 1904, c'est-à-dire sous l'empire du nouveau Code, et cela en matière de crimes, de délits et de contraventions.

Il a été rendu dans la période précitée 1.448 jugements contre les jeunes délinquants, dont 1.199 condamnations à la correction corporelle, 87 jugements ordonnant la remise des inculpés à leurs parents ou tuteurs, 69 jugements ordon nant de confier les inculpés à l'école de ré forme, 8 condamnations ordonnant de confier les inculpés à l'école de réforme à l'emprison nement et 78 condamnations à l'amende.

div.head: Condamnations conditionnelles
div.p: Sous le régime du nouveau Code (du 15 avril jusqu'à fin décembre 1904) qui a intro duit pour la première fois le principe des con damnations conditionnelles ont été rendus des jugements d'emprisonnement avec sursis de l'exécution contre 27 personnes, savoir: 12 cultivateurs, 2 écrivains dans les banques, 1 m;edecin, 1 architecte, 1 fiki, 1 marchand, 1 confiseur, 1 boulanger, 1 portier, 1 peseur de blé, 1 élève, 1 barbier, et 3 sans métier. De ces personnes 3 ont été condamnées pour coups, 7 pour rixe, 4 pour vol, 5 pour homicide involontaire, 2 pour dissipation, 1 pour dé tournement, 1 pour outrage, 1 pour fausse dénonciation, 1 pour exposition d'un nouveau né au danger.

div.head: III. CONTRAVENTIONS.
div.p: 105.863 affaires de contraventions ont été examinées au Parquet.
Sur ce nombre 15.472 ont été classées sans suite faute d'éléments de poursuite, et 10.601 ont fait l'objet de transaction en vertu du décret du 10 février 1892.
Dans ce chiffre de 105.863 affaires de con traventions, la ville du Caire figure, à elle seule, pour 41,696 et la ville d'Alexandrie figure pour 24.255
En 1903, le nombre des contraventions s'éle vait à 144.158 dont 46.829 pour la ville du Caire et 27.253 pour la ville d'Alexandrie...

div.head: 1e. Tribunaux de première instance
div.p: Les sept tribunaux de première instance ont statué définitivement en degré d'appel sur 21.633 délits et contraventions jugés par les tribunaux sommaires et de markaz.
Dans 19.148 de ces affaires, il est intervenu des jugements de condamnations et dans 2.415 des jugements d'acquittement; et ce, outre 70 jugements d'incompétences...

div.head: 2e Cour d'Appel
div.p: Pendant le cours de l'année 1904, 2.756 affaires nouvelles ont été reçues au parquet général (au lieu de 3.037 en 1903). Elles se subdivisent en 1.241 crimes et 1.515 délits.

Elles ont été présentées, avec les affaires arriérées de l'année 1903, aux audiences de la Cour et il restait au parquet, le 31 décembre 1904, 126 crimes et 91 délits. En 1903, le nombre des affaires nouvelles était de 1.005 crimes et 2.032 délits; il restait au parquet, le 31 décembre 188 crimes et 516 délits.

La cour d'Appel a jugé en 1903, 2.687 affaires; et en 1904, 3.276 affaires se subdivi sant en 1.305 crimes et 1.971 délits. Sur ce nombre: 2.400 ont abouti à des condamna tions, 869 ont abouti à des acquittements; 7 ont été rayées du rôle.
(à suivre)

div.head: REGAINED FULL HEALTH AND STRENGTH THROUGH DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS
div.p: The strongest man has his moments of weak ness, when the body requires assistance. An example and a warning is the case of Mr. Charles Vosper, the amateur athlete, whose walking has won him fame. But of one race Mr. Vosper has vivid recollections, as gathered by a "Bournemouth Guardian" reporter. For once, Mr. Vosper's powers forsook him.

"Something was wrong with me," he said, "and I put it down to the effects of a suc cession of colds, and after that race I remained quite out of form until I regained my vigour through Dr. William's Pink Pills a few weeks ago.

"I am a carpenter by trade," continued the athlete when seen at Melbourne Granville road, Upper Parkstone, Dorset, "and up to the time I mentioned I had health and strength for all kinds of sport. After that, my troubles came fast. The least exertion tired me out until I feared I would never race again, I suf fered from depression and languor, and slept heavily at any time. I did not relish my meals. At times I seemed ter ribly weak, and my legs trembled. I felt un willing to take any exercise, and this feeling increased, until to walk at all became extreme ly trying. I did not seem to have any life, and a slight exertion exhausted me.

"I lost nearly a stone in weight, and became so haggard that my friends remarked upon it. Then came a remarkable change. My brother Henry, who suffered from dyspensia, was cured by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People. I began to take them when my trouble was at its height. My spirits brightened after two doses. Gradually the depression and languor left me. My wind and staying power improved, until now I am stronger and in better condition than ever before. I have taken three boxes of Dr. Williams' PInk Pills altogether, to which I owe my complete recovery."

Men are invariably careless about their health, with the result that from being de pressed and weak they frequently drift into a state of collapse. Nervous disorders sap the system of energy and render attention to business impossible, and these will eventually lead to Early Decay, Paralysis, and Locomoter Ataxy. There is food for the starved Nerves and Blood in Dr. Williams' Pink Pills, hence their continued success in Rheumatism, Scia tica, Neuralgia, St Vitus' Dance, and the nervous weaknesses which trouble both men and women. They cure also Anaemia, Indiges tion, Bile, Eczema, Kidney Disease, and ladies' ailments. But only the genuine Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People effect these many cures; substitutes cure nobody. Look for the seven words on every package, or if in doubt at any medicine shop send direct to Dr. WIlliams' Medicine Co., Holborn-visduct, enclosing 2s. 9d. for one box, or 13s. 19d. for six boxes.
